item.content:encoded: Leo M. Miyakoshi, Diego Marques-Coelho, Luiz E. R. De Souza, Flavia R. S. Lima, Vilma R. Martins, Silvio M. Zanata, Cecilia Hedin-Pereira

item.title: Trends in Neurosciences: The Role of Astrocyte Dysfunction in Parkinson’s Disease Pathogenesis
item.content:encoded: Astrocytes are the most populous glial subtype and are critical for brain function. Despite this, historically there have been few studies into the role that they may have in neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson’s disease (PD). Recently, however, several studies have determined that genes known to have a causative role in the development of PD are expressed in astrocytes and have important roles in astrocyte function. Here, we review these recent developments and discuss their impact on our understanding of the pathophysiology of PD, and the implications that this might have for its treatment.
item.dc:creator: Heather D.E. Booth, Warren D. Hirst, Richard Wade-Martins

item.title: Neuron: Netrin-Mediated Axon Guidance to the CNS Midline Revisited
item.content:encoded: Varadarajan et al. (2017)—in this issue of Neuron—and Dominici et al. (2017)—published online at Nature—independently show that floor plate-derived netrin-1 is dispensable for commissural neuron axon guidance to the CNS midline during development.
item.dc:creator: Randal A. Hand, Alex L. Kolodkin

item.title: Neuron: Synaptotagmins: That’s Why So Many
item.content:encoded: Synaptotagmin 7 (Syt7) was originally identified as a slow Ca2+ sensor for lysosome fusion, but its function at fast synapses is controversial. The paper by Luo and Südhof (2017) in this issue of Neuron shows that at the calyx of Held in the auditory brainstem Syt7 triggers asynchronous release during stimulus trains, resulting in reliable and temporally precise high-frequency transmission. Thus, a slow Ca2+ sensor contributes to the fast signaling properties of the calyx synapse.
item.dc:creator: Chong Chen, Peter Jonas

item.title: Neuron: Untangling a Cholinergic Pathway from Wakefulness to Memory
item.content:encoded: Acetylcholine is a major modulator of learning and memory, and its availability varies across the sleep-wake cycle. In this issue of Neuron, Papouin et al. describe a D-serine-dependent pathway involving astroglia by which the transmitter tunes the hippocampus toward memory encoding during wakefulness.
item.dc:creator: Steffen Gais, Monika Schönauer

item.title: Neuron: Editorial Note to: In Situ Transcription Profiling of Single Cells Reveals Spatial Organization of Cells in the Mouse Hippocampus
item.dc:creator: Sheel Shah, Eric Lubeck, Wen Zhou, Long Cai

item.title: Neuron: seqFISH Accurately Detects Transcripts in Single Cells and Reveals Robust Spatial Organization in the Hippocampus
item.content:encoded: In this Matters Arising Response to the Matters Arising (Cembrowski and Spruston, 2017), we demonstrate how the spatial heterogeneity seen using single-cell in situ analysis by seqFISH (Shah et al., 2016) holds even with low average abundance genes and that measuring hundreds of genes across wide expression ranges with seqFISH is informative for cell classification.
item.dc:creator: Sheel Shah, Eric Lubeck, Wen Zhou, Long Cai

item.title: Neuron: Rat mPFC and M2 Play a Waiting Game (at Different Timescales)
item.content:encoded: In this issue of Neuron, Murakami et al. (2017) relate neural activity in frontal cortex to stochastic and deterministic components of waiting behavior in rats; they find that mPFC biases waiting time, while M2 is ultimately responsible for trial-to-trial variability in decisions about how long to wait.
item.dc:creator: Angela J. Langdon, Andrew M. Wikenheiser, Geoffrey Schoenbaum

item.title: Neuron: A Map of Anticipatory Activity in Mouse Motor Cortex
item.content:encoded: Chen et al. mapped neuronal activity across regions and layers of the motor cortex during a tactile delayed response task. They found that activity anticipating future movement emerges first in deep layers of the anterior lateral motor cortex.
item.dc:creator: Tsai-Wen Chen, Nuo Li, Kayvon Daie, Karel Svoboda

item.title: Neuron: Dopamine Depletion Impairs Bilateral Sensory Processing in the Striatum in a Pathway-Dependent Manner
item.content:encoded: Ketzef et al. show that striatal sensory responses are altered in Parkinsonian mice. Specifically, the encoding of bilateral tactile inputs is impaired following dopamine depletion and restored by L-DOPA administration.
item.dc:creator: Maya Ketzef, Giada Spigolon, Yvonne Johansson, Alessandra Bonito-Oliva, Gilberto Fisone, Gilad Silberberg

item.title: Neuron: Ready, Steady, Go! Imaging Cortical Activity during Movement Planning and Execution
item.content:encoded: In this issue of Neuron, Chen et al. (2017) examine premotor activity representing motor planning, Allen et al. (2017) observe the global representation of goal-directed movement on the cortical network, and Makino et al. (2017) track changes in such dynamics throughout learning.
item.dc:creator: Arkarup Banerjee, Michael A. Long

item.title: Neuron: Tau at the Crossroads between Neurotoxicity and Neuroprotection
item.content:encoded: In contrast to the idea that tau phosphorylation is toxic, Ittner et al. (2016) recently showed that specific tau phosphorylation is neuroprotective, phenocopying tau ablation (DeVos et al., 2017), thus highlighting the complex tau biology that underlies neurotoxicity and neuroprotection.
item.dc:creator: Sarah L. DeVos, Bradley T. Hyman

item.title: Neuron: Diverse Requirements for Microglial Survival, Specification, and Function Revealed by Defined-Medium Cultures
item.content:encoded: Bohlen et al. describe a serum-free culture platform for microglia that recapitulates the morphology and process dynamics observed in vivo. They find that serum exposure enhances phagocytosis, and through transcriptomic characterizations show that signature gene expression requires continuous CNS instruction.
item.dc:creator: Christopher J. Bohlen, F. Chris Bennett, Andrew F. Tucker, Hannah Y. Collins, Sara B. Mulinyawe, Ben A. Barres

item.title: Neuron: Dynamic Palmitoylation Targets MAP6 to the Axon to Promote Microtubule Stabilization during Neuronal Polarization
item.content:encoded: Tortosa et al. show that MAP6 re-distributes from Golgi and secretory vesicles to axonal microtubules during neuronal polarization. Palmitoylation cycles control MAP6 membrane-microtubule shuttling. The authors also demonstrate the importance of MAP6 for microtubule stabilization, organelle trafficking, and axon maturation.
item.dc:creator: Elena Tortosa, Youri Adolfs, Masaki Fukata, R. Jeroen Pasterkamp, Lukas C. Kapitein, Casper C. Hoogenraad

item.title: Neuron: CaMKII Autophosphorylation Is Necessary for Optimal Integration of Ca2+ Signals during LTP Induction, but Not Maintenance
item.content:encoded: Chang et al. showed that CaMKII activation acts as a leaky integrator of Ca2+ pulses in dendritic spines, and demonstrated that phosphorylation of T286 is necessary for optimal integration of Ca2+ pulses during the induction of LTP but dispensable for the maintenance of LTP.
item.dc:creator: Jui-Yun Chang, Paula Parra-Bueno, Tal Laviv, Erzsebet M. Szatmari, Seok-Jin R. Lee, Ryohei Yasuda

item.title: Neuron: Distinct Sources of Deterministic and Stochastic Components of Action Timing Decisions in Rodent Frontal Cortex
item.content:encoded: Decisions are subject to both deterministic and stochastic influences. A study by Murakami et al. indicates that, in action timing decisions, these two components are differentially encoded in two areas of the rodent frontal cortex.
item.dc:creator: Masayoshi Murakami, Hanan Shteingart, Yonatan Loewenstein, Zachary F. Mainen

item.title: Neuron: Beyond Hat in Hand: Science Advocacy Is Foundational for Policy Decisions
item.content:encoded: Neuroscientists need to focus communications beyond advocating for research funding. By collaborating with communication researchers, neuroscientists can more effectively inform the public discourse and policymaker decisions. This enhances the value of neuroscience and helps use science to improve social outcomes.
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel Kendall-Taylor, Pat Levitt

item.title: Neuron: Non-nuclear Pool of Splicing Factor SFPQ Regulates Axonal Transcripts Required for Normal Motor Development
item.dc:creator: Swapna Thomas-Jinu, Patricia M. Gordon, Triona Fielding, Richard Taylor, Bradley N. Smith, Victoria Snowden, Eric Blanc, Caroline Vance, Simon Topp, Chun-Hao Wong, Holger Bielen, Kelly L. Williams, Emily P. McCann, Garth A. Nicholson, Alejandro Pan-Vazquez, Archa H. Fox, Charles S. Bond, William S. Talbot, Ian P. Blair, Christopher E. Shaw, Corinne Houart

item.title: Neuron: Walter J. Freeman: A Tribute
item.content:encoded: In the early 1960s, few neuroscientists attempted to model brain function using mathematics. Computers were slow and expensive, so numerical approximations of complex phenomena were out of reach in most cases, and scientists resorted primarily to analytical representations of simpler processes. The study of circuits was not new to Walter J. Freeman. He had started his education studying engineering at MIT (transferring later to the University of Chicago to study English) and was a radio operator in WWII.
item.dc:creator: Leslie M. Kay, Robert Kozma

item.title: Neuron: Linking Neurons to Network Function and Behavior by Two-Photon Holographic Optogenetics and Volumetric Imaging
item.content:encoded: Dal Maschio et al. introduce a suite of methods for simultaneous 3D two-photon optogenetics and multiplane functional imaging. This approach, which also includes reconstruction of single neurons, enabled the identification of circuitry driving motor behavior in larval zebrafish.
item.dc:creator: Marco dal Maschio, Joseph C. Donovan, Thomas O. Helmbrecht, Herwig Baier

item.title: Neuron: Indirect Pathway of Caudal Basal Ganglia for Rejection of Valueless Visual Objects
item.content:encoded: Kim et al. found a selective role of the indirect pathway in automatic saccades to visual objects. The pathway, originating from the caudate tail, selectively sends stable value information to the superior colliculus, thus suppressing saccades to historically bad objects.
item.dc:creator: Hyoung F. Kim, Hidetoshi Amita, Okihide Hikosaka

item.title: Trends in Neurosciences: Sustained Activity Encoding Working Memories: Not Fully Distributed
item.content:encoded: Working memory (WM) is the ability to remember and manipulate information for short time intervals. Recent studies have proposed that sustained firing encoding the contents of WM is ubiquitous across cortical neurons. We review here the collective evidence supporting this claim. A variety of studies report that neurons in prefrontal, parietal, and inferotemporal association cortices show robust sustained activity encoding the location and features of memoranda during WM tasks. However, reports of WM-related sustained activity in early sensory areas are rare, and typically lack stimulus specificity.
item.dc:creator: Matthew L. Leavitt, Diego Mendoza-Halliday, Julio C. Martinez-Trujillo

item.title: Trends in Neurosciences: Aberrant Network Activity in Schizophrenia
item.content:encoded: Brain dynamic changes associated with schizophrenia are largely equivocal, with interpretation complicated by many factors, such as the presence of therapeutic agents and the complex nature of the syndrome itself. Evidence for a brain-wide change in individual network oscillations, shared by all patients, is largely equivocal, but stronger for lower (delta) than for higher (gamma) bands. However, region-specific changes in rhythms across multiple, interdependent, nested frequencies may correlate better with pathology.
item.dc:creator: Mark J. Hunt, Nancy J. Kopell, Roger D. Traub, Miles A. Whittington

item.title: Trends in Neurosciences: Two sources of dopamine for the hippocampus
item.content:encoded: Dopaminergic signalling is established as playing an important role in novelty related modulation of hippocampal memory. Two recent studies have identified the noradrenergic fibres originating in the locus coeruleus as an additional source of neurotransmitter acting on dopaminergic receptors in the hippocampus.
item.dc:creator: Colin G. McNamara, David Dupret

item.title: Trends in Neurosciences: Seq-ing the Circuit Logic of the Basal Ganglia
item.content:encoded: Recently, Wallace et al. (2017) provide an unprecedented view of the layers of molecular, cellular and circuit complexity involving a basal ganglia output structure, the entopeduncular nucleus. Their findings lend order to chaos by revealing how molecularly and functionally defined cellular subsets are organized into distinct circuitry.
